pageContext.title: The story of Li Ka-shing, the billionaire who made early bets on Facebook, Spotify
pageContext.content:
With a personal wealth of US$30 billion, Li Ka-shing is one of those tycoons who’s an icon for entrepreneurs in all sectors.

“The most important enjoyment for me,” Li once said, “is to work hard and make more profit.”

Here’s how the Hong Kong industrialist built his empire and then made a beeline for the tech industry, including early investments in Facebook, Spotify, and Slack.

Fight and flight

Born in southern China’s Guangdong province in June 1928, the young Li had humble beginnings as the son of a primary school principal.

Li in 1975 / Photo credit: South China Morning Post

The family fled the Japanese invasion in 1940, heading to Hong Kong. Aged 12, Li started work at an uncle’s plastic watch-strap company, soon dropping out of school so that his income can support the family.

His father died from tuberculosis in 1942, shortly after Japanese troops seized control of Hong Kong, then a British territory.

Li meets Queen Elizabeth II in an undated photo. / Photo credit: Investors Conundrum

In 1950, the 22-year-old Li started his own business. After rising from a salesman to become manager of one of his uncle’s factories, Li used everything he’d learned in the past decade about plastics to start manufacturing plastic toys, before shifting to artificial flowers. He then set up his venture with about US$50,000.

Start of the empire

Hong Kong in the 1950s was roiled by riots amid a huge influx of refugees from China’s civil war, compounding already terrible, cramped conditions in the British colony. Li leapt on the chance to snap up commercial real estate on the cheap, giving birth to his real estate empire.

Li then rode Hong Kong’s 1960s boom as it morphed into an Asian tiger. His company evolved towards real estate development, building residential, office, retail, industrial, and hotel properties. In 1971, his firm launched an IPO in Hong Kong.

First big buy

In 1979, Li’s firm acquired a stake in 19th-century British trading house Hutchison Whampoa. It was a remarkable cultural milestone, showing Hong Kong’s growing strength on the basis of its own entrepreneurs.

Over the next decade, Li’s deal-making earned him the “Superman” nickname. Over the ’80s and ’90s, Li soon controlled much of the property dealing, port traffic, electric utilities, and telecommunications networks in Hong Kong.

Hong Kong industrialist Lawrence Kadoorie (L) and Li in 1981 / Photo credit: The Hong Kong Heritage Project

In 1986, Li’s already sprawling empire expanded to Canada – where his two sons were educated – with its stake in oil driller Husky Energy, in which he later took a controlling interest. He did likewise with the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce.

In the 1990s, he ventured into the UK with the Orange mobile phone network.

Following his philanthropic work via the Li Ka-shing Foundation, which began in the 1980s, the mogul said in 2006 that he’ll give away one-third of his wealth. His goal was to invest in education and healthcare projects around the world.

Photo credit: Li Ka Shing Foundation

“We all know the importance of identifying the right capital investment. Social capital is the key,” said Li at the time.

By 2018, the Foundation – which Li refers to as his “third son” – claims to have been involved in the educations of 120 million students as well as healthcare projects that have served 12 million patients.

Tech turn

With a booming tech industry comes billions of dollars in venture capital cash – and that’s what Li has in mind in 2006 when he opened his Hong Kong-based VC, Horizons Ventures.

It’s run by longtime friend Solina Chau, 56, who is also director of the Li Ka-shing Foundation.

Solina Chau interviewed on Hong Kong TV / Screengrab via Hketvideo

Li friends Facebook in 2007

A year later, Li invested in Facebook. Although not his first tech bet, the tycoon’s US$60 million funding for three-year-old Facebook indicated that Li wasn’t done with the diversification of his investments. He later put in US$60 million more.

Mark Zuckerberg in 2007 / Photo credit: Fast Company

At the time, Facebook – with 50 million active users – had already taken cash from Yahoo and Microsoft as investors clamored for a slice of Mark Zuckerberg’s could-be-bigger-than-MySpace social network.

Over the years, Horizons Ventures became particularly active across the US, Israel, and Europe.

Li visiting Stanford University in 2010 / Photo credit: EdTech Stanford University School of Medicine

By 2018, it’s taking a strong interest not just in consumer tech startups – like Slack and Spotify – but also in biotech and AI firms.
Among Horizons’ more unusual bets so far is lab-made whiskey and plant-based burgers.

Through Horizons, Li has so far invested more than US$420 million into startups.

Li retired in March 2018, weeks before his 90th birthday. His elder son Victor, 54, has taken over the reins of the conglomerate with its 323,000 employees and operations in 50 countries.
